I've encountered the following problem with JUnit 3.8.1.  I've written
a TestCase class and it has one testXXX() method and a tearDown()
override.  The tearDown() override does its own stuff and then calls
super.tearDown().

The problem is that both the testXXX() method I wrote and the
tearDown() method threw exceptions, and in fact, the error in
testXXX() was 
responsible for the failure of tearDown().  (I know, it wasn't the most
bulletproof test script, but it is what it is).

What I see that might be a JUnit bug is that the error in tearDown()
completely masked any output of the error thrown by testXXX(), so I
was led to the erroneous conclusion that testXXX() was succeeding. 
When I commented out the code in tearDown() that was throwing, then
and only then could I see the error in testXXX().  

Is this a feature of JUnit or a bug?
